A HYPERBOLIC SURFACE WITH A SQUARE GRID NET
LUKAS GEYER AND SERGEI MERENKOV

Abstract. We prove the existence of a hyperbolic surface spread over the
sphere for which the projection map has all its singular values on the extended
real line, and such that the preimage of the extended real line under the projection map is homeomorphic to the square grid in the plane. This answers a
question raised by È. B. Vinberg.

1. Introduction
According to the uniformization theorem, an open simply connected Riemann surface is conformally equivalent to either the complex plane C, or the open unit disc
D = {z ∈ C : |z| < 1}. In the former case it is said to be parabolic, and in the latter
it is called hyperbolic. We are interested in the application of the uniformization
theorem to clasically defined surfaces spread over the sphere.
A surface spread over the sphere is a pair (X, ψ), where X is a topological surface
and ψ : X → C a continuous, open and discrete map. Here C denotes the Riemann
sphere. The map ψ is called a projection. Two such surfaces (X1 , ψ1 ), (X2 , ψ2 ) are
equivalent , if there exists a homeomorphism φ : X1 → X2 , such that ψ1 = ψ2 ◦ φ.
According to a theorem of Stoı̈low [4], there exists a unique conformal structure on
X such that ψ is a holomorphic map. We call this the pull-back structure on X.
If X is open and simply connected, then as a Riemann surface with the pull-back
structure it is conformally equivalent to either C or D. Equivalent surfaces have
the same conformal type.
A continuous, open and discrete map ψ near each point z0 is homeomorphically
equivalent to a map z 7→ z k . The number k = k(z0 ) is called the local degree of
ψ at z0 . If k 6= 1, z0 is called a critical point and ψ(z0 ) a critical value. The set
of critical points is a discrete subset of X. A point a ∈ C is called an asymptotic
value of ψ, if there exists a curve γ : [0, t0 ) → X such that
γ(t) → ∞ and ψ(γ(t)) → a as t → t0 .
A point a ∈ C is called a singular value of ψ if a is either a critical or an asymptotic
value of ψ.
È. B. Vinberg [5] introduced the interesting class V of surfaces spread over the
sphere (X, ψ), such that all singular values of ψ are contained in R = R ∪ {∞}.
For such mappings ψ, the components of the preimages of the upper and lower
hemispheres are called cells. The preimage of the extended real line is a disjoint

union of the critical points, called vertices, and open arcs, called edges. Each vertex
has an even number (which is greater than or equal to four) of edges emanating from
it. The map ψ in this case is called a cellular map. The set ψ −1 (R), understood
as an embedded graph N in X, determines the topological properties of ψ. Such
an embedded graph N is called a net. Suppose that the edges of this graph are
labeled by positive numbers such that the sum over the edges of each cell is 2π. If
C is endowed with the spherical metric, we assume that ψ maps an edge labeled by
α onto an arc of length α. Since the length of the real line in the spherical metric
is 2π, this is possible. Equivalently, one can label the vertices of a net and ends of
edges going to infinity by points of C, so that the order of labels correspond to the
natural order on R.
It is an interesting question in which cases the conformal type of X is determined
by the combinatorics of a net, independent of the labeling. G. MacLane [2] and
Vinberg [5] considered the periodic net cos−1 (R). They showed that all labelings
of this net by real numbers and ∞, with ends of edges going to infinity labeled by
∞, produce parabolic surfaces.
In his paper, Vinberg asked whether the conformal type is determined by combinatorics in the case of the square grid net. It is clear that if the labels on the vertices
of every two adjacent square cells are symmetric with respect to their common edge,
the resulting surface is parabolic, and the corresponding cellular map is a fractional
linear transformation of some Weierstrass elliptic function. The main result of this
paper is the following theorem, which answers the question of Vinberg.
Theorem 1. There exists a hyperbolic surface of class V whose net is homeomorphic to the square grid.
From the point of view of the type problem, the class V is a generalization of a
classically studied class S. A surface spread over the sphere (X, ψ) is said to belong

Surfaces of class S have a combinatorial representation in terms of so-called labeled
Speiser graphs. Assume that (X, ψ) ∈ Fq and X is open. We fix a Jordan curve L,
visiting the points a1 , . . . , aq in cyclic order. The curve L is usually called a base
curve. It decomposes the sphere into two simply connected regions H1 , the region
to the left of L, and H2 , the region to the right of L. Let Li , i = 1, 2, . . . , q, be the
arc of L from ai to ai+1 (with indices taken modulo q). Let us fix points p1 in H1
and p2 in H2 , and choose q Jordan arcs γ1 , . . . , γq in C, such that each arc γi has
p1 and p2 as its endpoints, and has a unique point of intersection with L, which
is in Li . We take these arcs to be interiorwise disjoint, that is, γi ∩ γj = {p1 , p2 }
when i 6= j. Let Γ′ denote the graph embedded in C, whose vertices are p1 , p2 , and
whose edges are γi , i = 1, . . . , q, and let Γ = ψ −1 (Γ′ ). We identify Γ with its image
in R2 under an orientation preserving homeomorphism of X onto R2 . The graph Γ
has the following properties: It is infinite, connected, homogeneous of degree q, and
bipartite. A graph, properly embedded in the plane and having these properties is
called a Speiser graph, also known as a line complex . The vertices of a Speiser graph

3

Γ are traditionally marked by × and ◦, such that each edge of Γ connects a vertex
marked × with a vertex marked ◦. Each face of Γ, i.e. a connected component of
R2 \ Γ, has either a finite even number of edges along its boundary, in which case
it is called an algebraic elementary region, or infinitely many edges, in which case
it is called a logarithmic elementary region. Two Speiser graphs Γ1 , Γ2 are said
to be equivalent , if there is a sense-preserving homeomorphism of the plane, which
takes Γ1 to Γ2 .
The above construction is reversible. Suppose that the faces of a Speiser graph
Γ are labeled by a1 , . . . , aq , so that when going counterclockwise around a vertex
×, the indices are encountered in their cyclic order, and around ◦ in the reversed
cyclic order. We fix a simple closed curve L ⊂ C passing through a1 , . . . , aq . Let
H1 , H2 , L1 , . . . , Lq be as before. Let Γ∗ be the planar dual of Γ. If e is an edge of Γ∗
from a face of Γ marked aj to a face of Γ marked aj+1 , let ψ map e homemorphically
onto the corresponding arc Lj of L. This defines ψ on the edges and vertices of
Γ∗ . We then extend ψ to map the faces of Γ∗ homeomorphically to H1 and H2 ,
respectively. This defines a surface spread over the sphere (R2 , ψ) ∈ F (a1 , . . . , aq ).
The conformal structure is induced by the conformal structure of C if one considers
a copy of H1 or H2 for each face of Γ∗ , and glues H1 to H2 using the identity map
whenever the corresponding faces are adjacent. See [3] for further details.
The proof of Theorem 1 is in two parts. In Section 2 we construct a hyperbolic
surface of class S whose net is a certain degeneration of the square grid, namely some
of the sides of the grid are collapsed to a point. In Section 3 we use quasiconformal
deformations to obtain a surface of class V with the desired net. For a background
on the theory of quasiconformal maps see [1].
We would like to mention two interesting open questions connected to this result.
First, is it possible to find a hyperbolic surface spread over the sphere with combinatorics of the square grid, which has a labeling that is symmetric with respect
to a line? This would correspond to a real meromorphic map in the unit disc such
that the preimage of the extended real line is homeomorphic to the square grid.
The second question is whether MacLane-Vinberg's result still holds if one allows
non-symmetric labeling of the cosine net, i.e. whether the cosine net always gives a
parabolic surface in the case when we do not assume that labels on the ends of edges
going to infinity in the upper half-plane are the same as in the lower half-plane.
Acknowledgments. We would like to thank Alexandre Eremenko for suggesting
this problem and Mario Bonk for helpful discussions. We would also like to thank
the referee for valuable comments and for suggesting a simplification of the proof
in Section 2.

The Speiser graph Γ with so prescribed labeling defines a unique surface (X, ψ) of
class S, or, more precisely, of class F4 (0, 1/e, e, ∞). Here we assume that the base
curve is the extended real line. The rest of this section is devoted to the proof that
the surface (X, ψ) is of hyperbolic type.
We will show hyperbolicity by first cutting the surface into two parts A and B, and
finding explicit quasiconformal maps to horizontal strips. We then calculate the
asymptotics of the gluing maps and use a Theorem of L. I. Volkovyskiı̆ [6] to show
hyperbolicity of the resulting surface.

Quarterspheres here are the parts of the hemispheres outside the unit disc. Let A
be the complement of B in X. Then the interiors of A and B are simply connected

3. Unraveling logarithmic staircases
In this section we will use quasiconformal deformations of (X, ψ) to obtain a surface
of the same type with the net homeomorphic to the square grid.
A simply connected subsurface (Y, ψ) with Y ⊂ X is a logarithmic staircase over
a ∈ R in (X, ψ) if there exists c ∈ R such that ψ|Y : Y → De∗c (a) is a regular
covering map, i.e. there exists a conformal map φ : Y → {Re z < c} such that
ψ(z) = a + eφ(z) for z ∈ Y . The preimage of the real line consists of infinitely many
half-lines lk = (−∞, c) + iπk, k ∈ Z, in the φ-coordinate. A simply connected
subsurface (Y, ψ) is a logarithmic staircase over ∞ if (Y, 1/ψ) is a logarithmic
staircase over 0. The surface (X, ψ) contains infinitely many logarithmic staircases
over 0 and ∞.

Figure 3. Topological picture of the net of the cos-spine.
In order to obtain a surface whose net is homeomorphic to the square grid, we
will replace all of those logarithmic staircases by cosine spines. We say that (Y, ψ)
is a cos-spine in (X, ψ) if Y ⊂ X is simply connected, ψ is a cellular map, and
(ψ|Y )−1 (R) is a union of infinitely many lines l0 , l1 ,. . . , where l0 has one endpoint
on ∂Y , all other lines have two endpoints on ∂Y and l0 intersects every lk once, and
none of the other lk intersect (see Figure 3). The line l0 is the axis of symmetry of
the cos-spine.
Theorem 2. Let (X, ψ) be a Riemann surface spread over the sphere and (Y, ψ)
a logarithmic staircase over some a ∈ R in (X, ψ). Let z0 be a point on ∂Y with
ψ(z0 ) ∈ R. Endow X with the pull-back complex structure. Then there exists a
universal constant K > 1 and a K-quasiregular map ψ̃ : X → C with ψ̃ = ψ
outside Y and (Y, ψ̃) being a cos-spine whose axis of symmetry passes through z0 .
An immediate corollary is the following.
Corollary 1. Let (X, ψ) be a Riemann surface spread over the sphere and (Y1 , ψ),
(Y2 , ψ),. . . be mutually disjoint logarithmic staircases in (X, ψ). Furthermore, let zj
be a point on ∂Yj with ψ(zj ) ∈ R. Then there exists a Riemann surface (X, ψ̃) of
S
the same type as (X, ψ), where ψ̃ = ψ outside j Yj , and ψ̃|Yj is a cos-spine for
each j with its axis of symmetry passing through zj .
Proof. If we apply Theorem 2 to each logarithmic staircase separately, we obtain
a quasiregular map ψ̃ : X → C with the desired net. This implies that the conformal structures induced by ψ and ψ̃ are quasiconformally equivalent. The type of a
simply connected Riemann surface is preserved under quasiconformal homeomorphisms.
